Award.AwardTitle: Center of Excellence for Materials Research and Innovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Center of Excellence for Materials Research and Innovation (CEMRI)*, hosted by the Laboratory for Research on the Structure of Matter (LRSM) at the University of Pennsylvania (Penn), pursues a program that provides crucial support for faculty, post-docs, and graduate students drawn from different disciplines to tackle complex fundamental materials problems that can only be addressed in a truly collaborative mode, and that are likely to underlie future technologies and economic needs of society. Four Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs) are central to the Center. The first group explores the interplay of curvature- & elasticity-induced interactions in liquid crystals, colloids, and on interfaces; new findings will thus generate new abilities to manipulate soft matter using surface structures & membrane geometry. The second group creates materials inspired by virology from novel synthetic macromolecules such as self-assembled Janus dendrimers & designer proteins; the new materials, with virus-like structure & functions, will be useful for sensing, communication, and actuation. The third group investigates disordered packings of atoms, colloids and grains to understand how localized rearrangements of constituents organize under load; the new concepts generated will provide routes for predicting whether materials are about to fail, and for synthesis of tough materials. The fourth group, anchored by a world-class effort in nanocrystal synthesis & assembly, builds novel inter-dimensional materials from these particles, and measures emergent electronic, optical, acoustic and magnetic properties. In each IRG, theory and simulation stimulate experiment and vice versa, and answers to fundamental questions have implications for application and for the creation of heretofore un-synthesized advanced materials with unique properties. The CEMRI also supports Shared Experimental Facilities (SEFs) that enable the achievement of research goals, student/post-doc training, and outreach to our community. SEFs include X-ray scattering, electron and confocal microscopy, rheometry, electronic/thermal transport, magnetic responses, optical spectroscopy, scanning probe microscopy, and more.

The Penn CEMRI sustains creative educational and outreach programs for local K-12 school students and teachers, for undergraduates from around the nation, for Penn graduate students and post-docs, and for faculty, scientists, and students/post-docs from partnering institutions in the region and across the globe. A primary goal of the LRSM education and human resources development effort is to attract more Americans to STEM fields and take them to the highest educational level possible, with emphasis on underrepresented minorities, women, and the disabled. In addition to standard outreach programs such as Research Experiences for Undergraduates/Teachers (REU/RET), less common programs such as our Partnership for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) with the University of Puerto Rico, and distinctive programs such as our 4-week-High-School-PSSI and Southern Africa initiatives, CEMRI outreach will expand to include: the Girard School 7th Grade Science Camp for minority middle-school students, a year?long materials science elective course for high school seniors and associated workshops for teachers, annual materials exhibitions (with connections to NOVA, Philadelphia Science Festival), and Science Caf√©s for the general public. Local community is also embraced via imaginative telepresence such as Cable TV programs and MAGPI videoconferences to high schools (HS).

The CEMRI pursues a multi-faceted strategy to reach out to industry, national laboratories, and the international community. Currently, ~25 companies (small, medium and large) are directly involved with the CEMRI, and our Shared Experimental Facilities are widely used by local industries (~100 person-days per year). The COMPASS (Complex Assemblies of Soft Matter) Laboratory was started and will continue as a joint venture between the LRSM, Rhodia, and the French CNRS. The CEMRI also continues to play a role developing national synchrotron x-ray and neutron scattering facilities; more than 25% of CEMRI faculty are currently involved with National Labs as users or in collaborative projects; others serve on advisory panels. International links (i.e., joint workshops, reciprocal visits by faculty/post-docs/students) of CEMRI with institutes in Southern Africa, Germany, Japan, Taiwan, France, Romania, and more, have cemented genuine research ties worldwide.

*a NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC)

POR.DRECONTENT:
With critical assistance from the National Science Foundation, the University of Pennsylvania (Penn) materials community maintained an NSF Materials Research Science & Engineering Center (MRSEC, DMR 11-20901) for the period from 2011-17. The Laboratory for Research on the Structure of Matter (LRSM) at the University of Pennsylvania (Penn) hosted the MRSEC, whose broad mission was to discover new materials and innovative applications through collaborative interdisciplinary research. To this end: LRSM-MRSEC participants vigorously carried out our collaborative research program; LRSM-MRSEC developed infrastructure in the form of state-of-the-art characterization tools and shared facilities locally, regionally and nationally; LRSM-MRSEC faculty trained a competitive and diverse science & engineering work force that is in demand by US academe, government and industry. Moreover, per education and outreach, the LRSM fostered local, regional, national and international activities and partnerships with a goal to ensure that its research and education activities are harnessed for the good of society. In all of these activities, the LRSM has been fully committed to all aspects of diversity, with long-range goals to improve national pools of URMs, females, and disabled persons in all STEM activities.

The MRSEC provided core funding for LRSM activities that sustained high impact research (i.e., activities of ~50 faculty) and an array of education and human resources development (HRD) programs.

The 2011-17 MRSEC faculty collaboratively pursued four major research themes: Geometric Routes to Soft Assembly and Dynamics; Biologically-Inspired Janus-Dendrimer Assemblies; Mechanics of Disordered Packings; and Controlled Function in Inter-Dimensional Materials. Here, representative “best-work” highlights (selected by this director) from each IRG are summarized. In IRG-1, Yodh, Kamien, and Yang developed and demonstrated a novel concept in topological soft matter; they utilized the surface topography of a bilayer thin film to guide swelling-induced buckling behavior. Specifically, they showed that simple topographic patterning on the bilayer film can lead to formation of various 3D chiral structures, including half-pipes, helical tubules, and ribbons, based on a few physical constraints. The approach is attractive, in part, because it does not require sophisticated patterning techniques such as plasma etching or repeated photo-crosslinking with multiple masks. In IRG-2, Percec, Hammer, Klein, and Heiney developed several qualitatively new families of Janus Glycodendrimers (JGDs) that assemble into vesicles and other structures. This group includes mannose-containing dendrimers, fluorinated dendrimers, and glycodendrimercubosomes. Goulian and Percec then engineered hybrid dendrimersomes to target human epithelial cells using adhesin YadA, an outer membrane glycoprotein. In IRG-3, the group (all IRG PIs) collectively explored the concept of “softness” across a multi-scale disordered solid materials platform with constituents ranging from atomic/molecular to nano-/micro-particles to granular scales. One result was a high-profile publication in Science (co-authored by all IRG PIs) that found that softness spatial correlations decayed exponentially on length scales of order the interparticle spacing across all systems. Moreover, the measured ratio of rearrangement size to soft-region size was tightly distributed around unity for all systems. This work took first steps towards establishing causal structure-property relationships based on softness. In IRG-4, Kagan and Murray led an effort to use nanocrystal (NC) assembly to drive emergent electronic function. They developed surface ligands and ligand exchange methods to foster strong coupling between NCs, and introduced methods to dope NC assemblies. Resultant NC films exhibited dramatically increased mobilities and band-like transport. In a remarkable culmination of these efforts, they demonstrated the first electronic devices constructed entirely from NCs. They developed methods to stack device components constructed from metallic, semiconducting, and insulating NCs to realize high mobility, low voltage field-effect transistors fabricated on flexible plastic substrates.

 

The 2011-17 MRSEC hosted an array of education and outreach programs that targeted students at all levels, from K-12 to undergraduates, post-docs, teachers, small college faculty, regional academe, industrial, and governmental scientists, and the general public. The MRSEC sustained important core education & outreach programs. For example, by combining MRSEC funds with REU-site grants, our REU program engaged 149 students (with 42% minority and 75% from under-represented groups). Another successful annual core program was our Pennsylvania Summer Science Initiative (PSSI), a 4-week summer program for HS students; this program accepted 196 students from 2011-17 (with 74% URG, 34% minority, and 82% from public schools). The 2011-17 MRSEC also developed important new initiatives. A new Field Trip Series was started, introducing middle and high school students to materials science and giving them extensive exposure to a clean room. Most recently, we added students from a second school to our Middle School Science Camp; previously the students came entirely from Girard College, a school run by the City of Philadelphia for disadvantaged minority students from single parent families. Now, approximately half of the students come from the Pennsylvania School for the Deaf. The program’s clear success will ensure that it is maintained in our MRSEC portfolio.
